description: From extrovert +â€Ž -sion, a variant of extraversion popularized in psychology by Phyllis Blanchard's use of the variant (then nonstandard) spelling extrovert in her 1918 "Psycho-Analytic Study of August Comte".

definitionGroups.group: The state or quality of being extroverted or an extrovert, particularly:

entries.meaning: (religion, obsolete) Consideration of the material world as an aid to spiritual insight.
examples: in mystical Divinity... a scattering or distracting ones thoughts upon exterior objects.

entries.meaning: (medicine) The condition of being inside out, especially in relation to the bladder.
examples: In extroversion of the bladder the anterior part of this organ is more or less completely wanting.

entries.meaning: (informal psychology) A personality orientation towards others and things outside oneself; behavior expressing such orientation.
examples: Extroversion is the thrusting out of the mind on to life, the use of the mind in practical affairs, the pouring out of the libido on external objects.
